bug.short_desc: The server created by the 'source-server' sometimes crashes

long_desc.thetext: Creating a server on Win8 works only occasionally. Most of the time, the first load works as expected but using it for some time, the server stops and does not restart or either stops with a corresponding error message.

The culprit is IE (IE9 and IE10, in varying degrees). All works fine in other browsers (FF, Chr, Opr). IE is clogging up the Python web server. It stalls on a data connection, when downloading a file (e.g. one of the script files of the app), thereby also stalling the simple web server. Killing IE will resolve the sitatuation, bringing the web server back to functioning. Some SO commenter speaks about content length and response chunking [1].
I would need to dig deeper into that to find the actual cause, prob. using a packet sniffer like Wireshark or CharlesProxy. Other "small" web servers have the same problem (I've tested with newLisp, node.js would be another candidate). As this is going to far for the release, postpone this until after.
The work-around is to use some "major" web server that supposedly handle HTTP traffic more subtlely. I tested with nginx for Windows which works fine. Using this to serve the app also the reload-server works with IE.
[1] http://stackoverflow.com/a/12098951/127465

Re. other "small" servers:
Node.js-base 'node-static' server seems to cope fine with IE10 when using manual refresh of the app in the browser (i.e. the app refreshes reasonably fast). Using the reload-server is still wanky (The client pull requests are sent, but the server never "signals" a new version to the browser).
